list.title: Question 1
list.content: In this question give all angles in radians. Let $z = 1 + 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ and $w = 4 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$. - Find $z+w$. [1] - Find: - $|z+w|$; - $\arg(z+w)$. [2] - Find $\theta$, the angle shown on the diagram below. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/50c10ba6-2e1a-451a-9954-0ba12b6fac75/images/e3abd6a6-8ddf-4035-ba97-a07d91ca55c7/9f1b9b167af97e4b2c9ee84b7c9014f2cdaf63c7.svg)
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  z+w &= (1+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}) + (4 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}) \\[6pt]
  &= (1+4) + (2+1){\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 5 + 3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - The modulus of $z+w$ is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    |z+w| &= \sqrt{5^2 + 3^2} \hspace{6.3em} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 5.83}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - The argument of $z+w$ is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \arg(z+w) &= \tan^{-1}(3/5) \hspace{7.25em} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 0.540}\end{aligned}
    $$


- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.7em} \theta &= \arg z - \arg (z+w) \\[6pt]
  &= \tan^{-1}(2/1) - \tan^{-1}(3/5) \\[6pt]
  &= (1.107148\dots) - (0.540419\dots) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 0.567}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 2
list.content: Let $z = 2+{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ and $w = 1-2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$. - Find $zw$. [2] - Illustrate $z$, $w$ and $zw$ on the same Argand diagram. [3] - Let $\theta$ be the angle between $zw$ and $w$. Find $\theta$, giving your answer in radians.[2]
list.markScheme:
- The product of $z$ and $w$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  zw &= (2+{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})(1-2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}) \\[6pt]
  &= 2-4{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}+{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}+2 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 4-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we illustrate $z$, $w$ and $zw$ on the same Argand diagram, we
have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ce332d8e-4a39-41c6-929d-bcab05130838/images/e0dad541-eddc-48d6-bc66-b3dc162fa6c1/96f14dbc4defd6873946ae02a45c2e643f791342.svg)


- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \arg w &= \tan^{-1}((-2)/1) \\[6pt]
  &= -1.107148\dots \hspace{1.3em} \end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \arg zw &= \tan^{-1}((-3)/4) \\[6pt]
  &= -0.643501\dots \hspace{1.8em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8em} \theta &= |\arg w| - |\arg zw| \\[6pt]
  &= (1.107148\dots) - (0.643501\dots) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 0.464}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 3
list.content: The complex numbers $z$ and $w$ correspond to the points A and B as shown on the diagram below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f49c4a4e-a8b9-40a0-9883-70b2dab8b609/images/f51352cb-3ef3-4ded-8d97-25718787a7a9/0c46fa70e78de8ef6fa11a8d28566cc1742d4a83.svg) - Find the exact value of $|z - w|$. [2] - - Find the exact perimeter of triangle AOB. - Find the exact area of triangle AOB. [4]
list.markScheme:
- Using the cosine rule, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} |z - w|^2 &= |z|^2 + |w|^2 - 2|z||w|\cos\left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right) \\[6pt]
  |z - w|^2 &= 5^2 + 5^2 - 2(5)(5)\hspace{-0.1em} \bigg[\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\bigg] \\[10pt]
  |z - w|^2 &= 25(2-\sqrt{3}) \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{|z - w| = \textstyle 5\sqrt{2-\sqrt{3}}} \hspace{4.3em}
  $$

- 
  - The exact perimeter of triangle AOB is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \text{perimeter} &= |z| + |w| + |z-w| \\[6pt]
    &= 5 + 5 + \textstyle 5\sqrt{2-\sqrt{3}} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \textstyle 10 + 5\sqrt{2-\sqrt{3}}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - The exact area of triangle AOB is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.1em} \text{area} &= \dfrac{1}{2}|z||w|\sin\left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right) \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{1}{2}(5)(5)\hspace{-0.1em}\bigg[\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg] \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \dfrac{25}{4}}\end{aligned}
    $$

list.title: Question 4
list.content: Let $z_1 = 2\sqrt{3}\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(\dfrac{7\pi}{12}\Big)$, $z_3 = 2\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\theta$, and $z_2 = z_1 + z_3$ be represented by the points A, B and C on an Argand diagram as shown below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4cd04149-8449-4105-9b22-5e42b343e164/images/0085c6d0-51f3-4387-8aec-3a391223c6f4/f4ed9162ce8f5fbe06e47de0f00519455d24ad0d.svg) The shape OABC is a rectangle. - Show that $\theta = \dfrac{\pi}{12}$. [1] - Find $\arg\hspace{0.05em}(z_1 - z_2)$. [1] - Express $z_2$ in modulus-argument form. [4]
list.markScheme:
- From the diagram, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \theta &= \arg z_1 - \text{A\^{O}C} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{7\pi}{12} - \dfrac{\pi}{2} = \hspace{0.525em}\answer{\dfrac{\pi}{12}} \hspace{1em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we illustrate $z_1 - z_2$ on the same Argand diagram, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4cd04149-8449-4105-9b22-5e42b343e164/images/04442292-e044-4715-9411-67fdf5174007/61b40c253f2d12de7c4ab40eafed5e3eb9ac59d0.svg)


  Hence the argument of $z_1 - z_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \arg\hspace{0.05em}(z_1 - z_2) &= \text{C\^{O}D} - \arg z_3 \hspace{0.75em} \\[14pt]
  &= \pi - \dfrac{\pi}{12} \\[8pt]
  &\answer{= -\dfrac{11\pi}{12}}\end{aligned}
  $$

  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4cd04149-8449-4105-9b22-5e42b343e164/images/04442292-e044-4715-9411-67fdf5174007/61b40c253f2d12de7c4ab40eafed5e3eb9ac59d0.svg)


- Using the right triangle OBC, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} |z_2|^2 &= |z_1|^2 + |z_3|^2 \\[6pt]
  |z_2|^2 &= (2\sqrt{3})^2 + 2^2 \hspace{0.2em} \\[6pt]
  |z_2|^2 &= 16 \\[7pt]
  |z_2| &= 4\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using the right triangle OBC again, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.4em} \cos(\text{B\^{O}C}) &= \dfrac{|z_3|}{|z_2|} \\[6pt]
  \cos(\text{B\^{O}C}) &= \dfrac{2}{4} \hspace{3em} \left(=\dfrac{1}{2}\right) \\[9pt]
  \text{B\^{O}C} &= \dfrac{\pi}{3}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} \arg z_2 &= \arg z_3 + \text{B\^{O}C} \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{\pi}{12} + \dfrac{\pi}{3} \\[8pt]
  &= \dfrac{5\pi}{12}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, if we write $z_2$ in
modulus-argument form, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} \answer{z_2 = 4\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(\dfrac{5\pi}{12}\Big)}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 5
list.content: A circle is drawn on an Argand diagram as shown below. The tangent to the circle from the point B$(0,9)$ meets the circle at the point A as shown. Let $w = \vv{\mathrm{OA}}$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a933f476-df41-4384-9ff1-38ce595a983f/images/a7e2f81c-7176-46a6-9367-c80340035fc4/756bc10d49856365edc8188e18631d432452e02d.svg) - Show that $|w| = 3\sqrt{3}$. [2] - Find $\arg w$. [2] - Hence write $w$ in the form $a+b{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ where $a, b \in \mathbb{R}$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a933f476-df41-4384-9ff1-38ce595a983f/images/5eb70fb9-568d-4a68-b0f3-a7ba593cbbc1/be4795ddca85773f31f1a7dd616d51f34bbef9b7.svg)


  Using the right triangle ABC, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.4em} \cos(\text{A\^{C}B}) &= \dfrac{3}{6} \hspace{3em} \left(=\dfrac{1}{2}\right) \\[6pt]
  \text{A\^{C}B} &= \dfrac{\pi}{3} \\[6pt]
  \text{A\^{C}O} &= \dfrac{2\pi}{3}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the
cosine rule, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.4em} |w|^2 &= 3^2 + 3^2 - 2(3)(3)\cos \Big(\dfrac{2\pi}{3}\Big) \\[3pt]
  |w|^2 &= 18 - 18\hspace{-0.1em}\left[-\dfrac{1}{2}\right] \\[6pt]
  |w|^2 &= 27 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{|w| = 3\sqrt{3}} \hspace{0.9em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a933f476-df41-4384-9ff1-38ce595a983f/images/5eb70fb9-568d-4a68-b0f3-a7ba593cbbc1/be4795ddca85773f31f1a7dd616d51f34bbef9b7.svg)


- Using the isosceles triangle OAC, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} \text{A\^{O}C} &= \dfrac{1}{2}\hspace{0.05em}(\pi - \text{A\^{C}O}) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1}{2}\bigg[\pi - \dfrac{2\pi}{3}\bigg] \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{\pi}{6}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the argument of $w$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.5em} \arg w &= \dfrac{\pi}{2} - \text{A\^{O}C} \\[8pt]
  &= \dfrac{\pi}{2} - \dfrac{\pi}{6} \\[8pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{\pi}{3}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we write $w$ in Cartesian form, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6.4em} w &= 3\sqrt{3}\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\left(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\right) \\[9pt]
  &= 3\sqrt{3}\bigg[\hspace{-0.1em}\cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\right) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \left(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\right)\hspace{-0.2em}\bigg] \\[6pt]
  &= 3\sqrt{3}\bigg[\dfrac{1}{2} + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\bigg] \\[7pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{3\sqrt{3}}{2} + \dfrac{9}{2}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 6
list.content: Consider the complex number $z$, such that $z=2\hspace{0.05em}e^{\frac{\pi}{a}i}$, where $|a|>1, a \in \mathbb{R}$. - Show that $z$ can never be a positive real number. [2] Now consider the complex number $w$, such that $w=-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{2}i$. There is one value of $a$ such that $\frac{z}{w}$ is a positive real number. - Find this value of $a$. [6]

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
On an Argand diagram, the complex numbers
$z_1 = 2 + 2\sqrt{3}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$,
$z_2 = 1 - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ and $z_3 = z_1z_2$ are
represented by the vertices of a triangle.
Find the area of the triangle.
list.markScheme:
We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.1em} |z_1| &= \textstyle \sqrt{2^2+(2\sqrt{3})^2} \\[6pt]
&= 4 \\[12pt]
|z_2| &= \sqrt{1^2+(-1)^2} \\[6pt]
&= \sqrt{2}\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\arg z_1 &= \tan^{-1}(2\sqrt{3}/2) \\[6pt]
&= \ang{60} \\[12pt]
\arg z_2 &= \tan^{-1}(-1/1) \\[6pt]
&= -\ang{45}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, using the property of modulus, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
|z_3| &= |z_1z_2| \\[6pt]
&= |z_1||z_2| \hspace{2.1em} \\[6pt]
&= 4\sqrt{2}\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\arg z_3 &= \arg(z_1z_3) \\[6pt]
&= \arg z_1 + \arg z_2 \\[6pt]
&= \ang{15}\end{aligned}
$$

If we sketch the triangle whose vertices
represent $z_1$, $z_2$ and $z_3$ on an Argand diagram, we have
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d9540a91-3a6d-402f-96f6-82e7e2baf51e/images/357aebcc-946f-48d1-9cb4-5216d45536d4/cce5162c3d61fa13f25a6e2323562142371b3997.svg)


Hence the area of the triangle ABC is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text{area(A\^{B}C)} &= \text{area(A\^{O}C)} + \text{area(B\^{O}C)} - \text{area(A\^{O}B)} \\[8pt]
&= \dfrac{1}{2}(4)(4\sqrt{2})\sin \ang{45} + \dfrac{1}{2}(\sqrt{2})(4\sqrt{2})\sin \ang{60} - \dfrac{1}{2}(4)(\sqrt{2})\sin \ang{105} \\[8pt]
&\answer{\approx 8.73}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
Consider two sinusoidal functions with the same period, $S_1$ and $S_2$, given by

$$
\begin{align*}
S_1= 8 \cos (bx - 30^{\circ}) \hspace{3em} \text{and} \hspace{3em} S_2 = 6 \cos (bx + 30^{\circ})
\end{align*}
$$

The two sinusoidal functions are combined to make the equation $S_1+S_2 = A \cos \left(bx + \alpha\right)$.
Find the value of $A$ and the value of $\alpha$.

list.title: Question 9
list.content: Consider two power sources with voltages $V_1$ and $V_2$ respectively, where $\omega$ is the frequency of the power source in Hertz (Hz) and $t$ is time in seconds. It is given that $$ \begin{align*} V_1 = 161\sin(\omega t + 1.047)\,. \end{align*} $$ When the two power sources are combined, the resultant voltage $V_1 + V_2$ is given by $$ \begin{align*} V_T = 240\sin(\omega t + 1.883)\,. \end{align*} $$ - Find $V_2$. Give your answer in the form $a\sin(\omega t + b)$, where $a,b \in \mathbb{R}$.[6] - Hence, determine the difference in phase shift between $V_1$ and $V_2$.[2]

list.title: Question 10
list.content: Points A and B represent the complex numbers $z_1 = \sqrt{3} - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ and $z_2 = -3 - 3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ as shown on an Argand diagram below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4606175f-76d3-4bb2-97cc-8d9498e9a9bb/images/aea79791-5595-4133-ad16-58283147a4b9/b9acbcc9be3dbe232f939a960c2a1907744b9b96.svg) - Find the angle AOB. [2] - Find the argument of $z_1z_2$. [1] - Given that the real powers of $pz_1z_2$, for $p > 0$, all lie on a unit circle centred at the origin, find the exact value of $p$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \arg z_1 &= \tan^{-1}\left(\hspace{-0.2em}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\hspace{-0.1em}\right) \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{\pi}{6}\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \arg z_2 &= \tan^{-1}(1) \hspace{0.9em} \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{\pi}{4} - \pi \\[8pt]
  &= -\dfrac{3\pi}{4}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.3em} \text{A\^{O}B} &= |\arg z_2| - |\arg z_1| \\[10pt]
  &= \dfrac{3\pi}{4} - \dfrac{\pi}{6} \\[7pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{7\pi}{12}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The argument of $z_1z_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \arg(z_1z_2) &= \arg z_1 + \arg z_2 \\[10pt]
  &= -\dfrac{\pi}{6} - \dfrac{3\pi}{4} \\[7pt]
  &\answer{= -\dfrac{11\pi}{12}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.2em} |z_1| &= \textstyle \sqrt{(\sqrt{3})^2 + (-1)^2} \\[6pt]
  &= \sqrt{4} \\[8pt]
  &= 2\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.1em} |z_2| &= \sqrt{(-3)^2 + (-3)^2} \\[6pt]
  &= \sqrt{18} \\[6pt]
  &= 3\sqrt{2}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the properties of modulus,
we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.7em} |(pz_1z_2)^x| &= 1 \hspace{3em} [\text{for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$}] \\[12pt]
  |pz_1z_2|^x &= 1 \\[12pt]
  |pz_1z_2| &= 1 \\[12pt]
  |p||z_1||z_2| &= 1 \\[12pt]
  p\hspace{0.05em}(2)(3\sqrt{2}) &= 1  \hspace{3em} [\text{since $p > 0$}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{p = \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{12}} \hspace{2.6em}
  $$

list.title: Question 11
list.content: Let $z = \sqrt{2}\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\hspace{-0.1em}\left(\dfrac{3\pi}{8}\right)$ and $w = 2\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\hspace{-0.1em}\bigg(\dfrac{n\pi}{24}\bigg)$ , where $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$. - Find the value of $z^6$. Give your answer in the form $re^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\theta}$, where $r \geq 0$, $-\pi < \theta \leq \pi$. [2] - Find the value of $(wz)^4$ for $n = 5$. Give your answer in the form $re^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\theta}$, where $r \geq 0$, $-\pi < \theta \leq \pi$. [3] - Find the smallest integer $n > 9$ such that $\dfrac{z}{w} \in \mathbb{R}$. [3]
list.markScheme:
We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
z &= \sqrt{2}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{3\pi}{8}} \\[12pt]
w &= 2e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{n\pi}{24}} \hspace{1em} \\
\end{aligned}
$$


- Therefore

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  z^6 &= \left(\sqrt{2}\,e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{3\pi}{8}}\right)^6 \\[12pt]
  &= 8e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{9\pi}{4}} \\[12pt]
  &= 8e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\left(\frac{9\pi}{4} - 2\pi\right)} \hspace{0.75em} [\text{so that $-\pi < \theta \leq \pi$}] \\[12pt]
  &\hspace{-0.9em}\answer{z^6 = 8e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{4}}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (wz)^4 &= \Big[\big(2e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{5\pi}{24}}\big)\hspace{-0.2em}\big(\sqrt{2}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{3\pi}{8}}\big)\Big]^{4} \hspace{3em} [\text{for $n=5$}] \\[12pt]
  &= \Big[2\sqrt{2}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\left(\frac{5\pi}{24} + \frac{3\pi}{8}\right)}\Big]^{4} \\[12pt]
  &= \big(2\sqrt{2}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{7\pi}{12}}\big)^{4} \\[12pt]
  &= 64e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{7\pi}{3}} \\[12pt]
  &= 64e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(\frac{7\pi}{3}- 2\pi)} \hspace{0.75em} [\text{so that $-\pi < \theta \leq \pi$}] \\[12pt]
  &\hspace{-2.5em}\answer{(wz)^4 = 64e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{3}}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The quotient $\dfrac{z}{w}$ is a real number when
$\arg\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(\dfrac{z}{w}\Big)$ is a multiple of $\pi$.
We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{z}{w} &= \dfrac{\sqrt{2}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{3\pi}{8}}}{2e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{n\pi}{24}}} \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\left(\frac{3\pi}{8} - \frac{n\pi}{24}\right)} \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\left(\frac{9-n}{24}\right)\pi} \\[12pt]
  \arg\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(\dfrac{z}{w}\Big) &= \left(\frac{9-n}{24}\right)\pi\\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Therefore the smallest integer $n > 9$ such that
$\dfrac{z}{w} \in \mathbb{R}$ is
$\answer{n = 33}$

list.title: Question 12
list.content: Let $z = re^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{3}}$ where $r \in \mathbb{R}^+$. - For $r = \sqrt{2}$, - express $z^2$ and $z^3$ in the form $a+b{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ where $a, b \in \mathbb{R}$; - draw $z^2$ and $z^3$ on the following Argand diagram. [4] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/eecd4b7e-d849-40ed-986b-85883ff7b716/images/f2f17a3e-671d-4ce2-8659-1788668037b1/7e711daec273ec9c0f630b852aae229a5a09d558.svg) - Given that the integer powers of $w = (3-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})\hspace{0.05em}z$ lie on a unit circle centred at the origin, find the value of $r$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - If we express $z^2$ and $z^3$ in Cartesian form, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{5.5em} z^2 &= 2e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{2\pi}{3}} \\[9pt]
    &= 2\Big[\hspace{-0.1em}\cos\Big(\frac{2\pi}{3}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin\Big(\frac{2\pi}{3}\Big)\Big] \\[9pt]
    &\answer{=-1 + \sqrt{3}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} \end{aligned}
    $$

    and

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3em} z^3 &= 2\sqrt{2}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\pi} \\[9pt]
    &= 2\sqrt{2}\Big[\hspace{-0.1em}\cos \pi + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \pi \Big] \\[9pt]
    &\answer{=-2\sqrt{2} + 0{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - If we draw $z^2$ and $z^3$ on the following Argand diagram, we
have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/eecd4b7e-d849-40ed-986b-85883ff7b716/images/ded0ec5a-bcd5-4df9-ad7f-598af8270fb2/ee3e2d0e8670f88c39e4d0221f05849bcdba3ebd.svg)



- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  |3-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}| &= \sqrt{3^2 + (-3)^2} \\[6pt]
  &= \sqrt{18} \\[6pt]
  &= 3\sqrt{2}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the properties of modulus,
we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  |w^k| &= 1 \hspace{3em} [\text{for all $k \in \mathbb{Z}$}]  \\[13pt]
  |w|^k &= 1 \\[14pt]
  |w| &= 1 \\[14pt]
  \hspace{3.1em} |(3-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})z| &= 1 \hspace{3em} [w = (3-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})z] \\[14pt]
  |3-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}||z| &= 1 \\[12pt]
  3\sqrt{2}\hspace{0.05em}r &= 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{r = \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{6}} \hspace{1.4em}
  $$

list.title: Question 13
list.content: Let $z = re^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{6}}$ where $r \in \mathbb{R}^+$. - For $r = \sqrt{3}$, - express $z^2$ and $z^3$ in the form $a+b{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ where $a, b \in \mathbb{R}$; - draw $z^2$ and $z^3$ on the following Argand diagram. [4] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f8b7f053-da8d-4e58-93be-10882e6392eb/images/92508df3-14ba-4834-b3e9-4f2f3338ae54/633c15de281dbaeb852d4279b825abc3a94854e8.svg) - Given that the integer powers of $w = \dfrac{z}{6+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}$ lie on a unit circle centred at the origin, find the value of $r$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - If we express $z^2$ and $z^3$ in Cartesian form, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{4em} z^2 &= 3e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{3}} \\[10pt]
    &= 3\Big[\hspace{-0.1em}\cos\Big(\frac{\pi}{3}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin\Big(\frac{\pi}{3}\Big)\Big] \\[4pt]
    &\answer{=\dfrac{3}{2} + \dfrac{3\sqrt{3}}{2}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
    $$

    and

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{5.3em} z^3 &= 3\sqrt{3}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{2}} \\[10pt]
    &= 3\sqrt{3}\Big[\hspace{-0.1em}\cos\Big(\frac{\pi}{2}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin\Big(\frac{\pi}{2}\Big)\Big] \\[10pt]
    &\answer{=0+3\sqrt{3}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - If we draw $z^2$ and $z^3$ on the following Argand diagram, we
have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f8b7f053-da8d-4e58-93be-10882e6392eb/images/269127e3-b920-40c3-9c56-96e0a5491f22/ecdfaa8e1f1031e684d45d25638e79596842fb1a.svg)



- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  |6+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}| &= \sqrt{6^2 + 2^2} \hspace{2.2em} \\[6pt]
  &= \sqrt{40} \\[6pt]
  &= 2\sqrt{10}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the properties of modulus,
we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  |w^k| &= 1 \hspace{3em} [\text{for all $k \in \mathbb{Z}$}]  \\[16pt]
  |w|^k &= 1 \\[17pt]
  |w| &= 1 \\[15pt]
  \hspace{3.9em} \Big|\dfrac{z}{6+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\Big| &= 1 \hspace{3em} [w = z/(6+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})] \\[8pt]
  \dfrac{|z|}{|6+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}|} &= 1 \\[9pt]
  \dfrac{r}{2\sqrt{10}} &= 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{r = 2\sqrt{10}} \hspace{1.3em}
  $$

list.title: Question 14
list.content: Two voltage sources are connected to a circuit. At time $t$ milliseconds (ms), the voltage from the first source is $V_1(t) = 12\cos(20t)$ and the voltage from the second source is $V_2(t) = 18\cos(20t+5)$, where both $V_1(t)$ and $V_2(t)$ are measured in volts. - Write, in the form $V(t) = A\cos\hspace{0.05em}(\omega t+\varphi)$, an expression for the total voltage in the circuit at time $t$ ms. [4] - Hence write down the highest voltage in the circuit. [1]
list.markScheme:
- The total voltage in the circuit at time $t$ ms is given by
$V(t) = V_1(t) + V_2(t)$.
  Hence we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} V(t) &= 12\cos(20t) + 18\cos(20t+5) \\[7pt]
  &= \mathrm{Re}\big[12\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}(20t) + 18\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}(20t+5)\big] \\[6pt]
  &= \mathrm{Re}\big[12e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}20t} + 18e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(20t+5)}\big]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we further have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  12e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}20t} + 18e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(20t+5)} &= e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}20t}\big[12 + 18e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}5}\big] \\[6pt]
  &\approx e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}20t}\big[17.1 - 17.3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\big] \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\[6pt]
  &\approx e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}20t}\big[24.3e^{-{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}0.790}\big] \hspace{3.1em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\[6pt]
  &\approx 24.3e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(20t-0.790)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  V(t) &\approx \mathrm{Re}\big[24.3e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(20t-0.790)}\big] \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 24.3\hspace{0.05em}\cos(20t-0.790)} \hspace{3em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Hence the highest voltage in the circuit is
$\answer{24.3\hspace{0.25em}\text{volts}}$

list.title: Question 15
list.content: The sunset time in Paris can be modelled by the function $$ \mathrm{S}(t) = 1.85\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.52\hspace{0.05em}t - 1.57) + 19.5 $$ where $t$ is time in months, from the beginning of January. The sunrise time can similarly be modelled by $$ \mathrm{R}(t) = 1.35\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.52\hspace{0.05em}t - 4.7) + 7.5 $$ Both $\mathrm{S}(t)$ and $\mathrm{R}(t)$ are measured in hours since midnight. $\mathrm{S}(t)$ can be expressed as $\mathrm{im}(z_1)+19.5$ and $\mathrm{R}(t)$ can be expressed as $\mathrm{im}(z_2)+7.5$, where $z_1,z_2 \in \mathbb{C}$. - Write down expressions for $z_1$ and $z_2$. Give your answers in the form $z_{1,2}=r\,e^{\theta i}$.[2] The number of daylight hours in Paris, $\mathrm{D}(t)$, is given by $\mathrm{D}(t)=\mathrm{S}(t)-\mathrm{R}(t)$. - Hence show that the number of hours of daylight in Paris can be modelled by the function $$ \mathrm{D}(t)=3.20\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.52t-1.57) + 12 $$ [6] - According to the model, find: - the highest number of hours of daylight in a year; - The approximate number of months per year in which there is at least 14 hours of daylight. [5]

list.title: Question 16
list.content: Ali is swimming in a public pool with some of his friends. At time $t$ seconds, he $\text{encounters}$ some waves with height $h_1(t) = 0.15\sin\hspace{0.05em}(3t)$ from big Bobby jumping into the pool, and waves of height $h_2(t) = 0.08\sin\hspace{0.05em}(3t+1.25)$ from small Suzie jumping into the pool. Both $h_1(t)$ and $h_2(t)$ are measured in metres. - Write, in the form $h(t) = A\sin\hspace{0.05em}(\omega t+\varphi)$, an expression for the total height of the waves Ali encounters at time $t$ seconds. [3] - Find the times in the first $5$ seconds when Ali isn't affected by any waves. [2] - Find the first time when the waves reaching Ali has maximum height. [1]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  h(t) &= h_1(t) + h_2(t) \\[9pt]
  &= 0.15\sin\hspace{0.05em}(3t) + 0.08\sin\hspace{0.05em}(3t+1.25) \\[8pt]
  &= \mathrm{Im}\big[0.15\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\hspace{0.05em}(3t) + 0.08\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\hspace{0.05em}(3t+1.25)\big] \\[8pt]
  &= \mathrm{Im}\big[0.15e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}3t} + 0.08e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(3t+1.25)}\big]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we further have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  0.15e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}3t} + 0.08e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(3t+1.25)} &= e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}3t}\big[0.15 + 0.08e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}1.25}\big] \\[8pt]
  &\approx e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}3t}\big[0.175+ 0.0759{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\big] \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\[8pt]
  &\approx e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}3t}\big[0.191e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}0.409}\big] \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\[8pt]
  &\approx 0.191e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(3t+0.409)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  h(t) &\approx \mathrm{Im}\big[0.191e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(3t+0.409)}\big] \\[8pt]
  &\answer{\approx 0.191\sin\hspace{0.05em}(3t+0.409)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = h(t)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8cbd4564-0681-4f42-b214-d4d91937919a/images/2b870085-23f9-4c2a-bcb0-7dbf9029b430/c1274d3811929d9ce0da7917e348fa7728bfc3fe.svg)


  Hence the times in the first $5$ seconds when Ali isn't affected by
any waves are

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{0.911\hspace{0.25em}\text{s},\hspace{0.25em} 1.96\hspace{0.25em}\text{s},\hspace{0.25em} 3.01\hspace{0.25em}\text{s},\hspace{0.25em} 4.05\hspace{0.25em}\text{s}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = h(t)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8cbd4564-0681-4f42-b214-d4d91937919a/images/91489501-8a21-4124-adbb-cc1a63b0c90e/ffc02fbfbe87991fd09c664afe4f4f0a2e6d0e8d.svg)


  Hence the first time when the wave reaching Ali has max height is at
$\answer{0.387\hspace{0.25em}\text{s}}$

list.title: Question 17
list.content: The revenues of a four seasons hotel can be modelled by the function $\mathrm{R}(t) = 58.2\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.0172t - 1.25) + 204$, where $t$ is the number of days after midnight on $31$ December. In a similar way, the operating costs of the hotel can be modelled by the function $\mathrm{C}(t) = 31.4\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.0172t + 1.14) + 85.0$. Both $\mathrm{R}(t)$ and $\mathrm{C}(t)$ are measured in thousand dollars. - Show that the profits of the hotel can be modelled by the function $\mathrm{P}(t) = 83.9\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.0172t-1.51) + 119$. [3] - According to the model, find: - the highest profit the hotel will make; - the date on which the highest profit will occur. [3]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \mathrm{P}(t) &= \mathrm{R}(t) - \mathrm{C}(t) \\[9pt]
  &= (58.2\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.0172t-1.25) + 204) - (31.4\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.0172t+1.14) + 85.0) \\[9pt]
  &= \big[58.2\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.0172t-1.25) - 31.4\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.0172t+1.14)\big] + (204 - 85.0) \\[9pt]
  &= \mathrm{Im}\big[58.2\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\hspace{0.05em}(0.0172t-1.25) - 31.4\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\hspace{0.05em}(0.0172t+1.14)\big] + 119 \\[8pt]
  &= \mathrm{Im}\big[58.2e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(0.0172t-1.25)} - 31.4e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(0.0172t+1.14)}\big] + 119\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we further have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  58.2e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(0.0172t-1.25)} - 31.4e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(0.0172t+1.14)} &= e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}0.0172t}\big[58.2e^{-{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}1.25} - 31.4e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}1.14}\big] \\[8pt]
  [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \hspace{3em} &\approx e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}0.0172t}\big[5.24-83.8{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\big] \\[8pt]
  [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \hspace{3em} &\approx e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}0.0172t}\big[83.9e^{-{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}1.51}\big] \\[8pt]
  &\approx 83.9e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(0.0172t-1.51)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \mathrm{P}(t) &\approx \mathrm{Im}\big[83.9e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(0.0172t-1.51)}\big] + 119 \\[8pt]
  &\answer{\approx 83.9\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.0172t-1.51) + 119}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - According to the model, the highest profit is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \mathrm{P_{max}} &\approx 83.9 + 119 \\[8pt]
    &\answer{\approx \$203 \text{ thousand}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - If we sketch the graph of $y = \mathrm{P}(t)$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a771343a-1612-47bb-9629-9a6f18d261c8/images/05fac9bf-641e-4d76-a847-d751b1246a59/543d375a9ce4d0222b972c2179c98d4a685548a5.svg)


    Hence the highest profit occurs on $\text{day } 179$ or
$\answer{\text{June } 28}$

list.title: Question 18
list.content: In an unbalanced three-phase electrical circuit, the current at time $t$ ms is given by $I(t) = 2\sin\hspace{0.05em}(5t) + 5\sin\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(5t-\dfrac{3\pi}{4}\Big) + 10\sin\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(5t-\dfrac{5\pi}{4}\Big)$, where $I(t)$ is measured in milliamperes (mA). - Write $I(t)$ in the form $A\cos\hspace{0.05em}(\omega t+\varphi)$. [4] - Hence find the highest current flowing through the circuit, and the time it first occurs. [2]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  I(t) &= 2\sin\hspace{0.05em}(5t) + 5\sin\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(5t-\dfrac{3\pi}{4}\Big) + 10\sin\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(5t-\dfrac{5\pi}{4}\Big) \\[6pt]
  &= \mathrm{Im}\Big[2\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\hspace{0.05em}(5t) + 5\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(5t-\dfrac{3\pi}{4}\Big) + 10\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(5t-\dfrac{5\pi}{4}\Big)\Big] \\[6pt]
  &= \mathrm{Im}\Big[2e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}5t} + 5e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\left(5t-\frac{3\pi}{4}\right)} + 10e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\left(5t-\frac{5\pi}{4}\right)}\Big] \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we further have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}5t} + 5e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\left(5t-\frac{3\pi}{4}\right)} + 10e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\left(5t-\frac{5\pi}{4}\right)} &= e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}5t}\big[2 + 5e^{-{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{3\pi}{4}} + 10e^{-{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{5\pi}{4}}\big] \\[8pt]
  &\approx e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}5t} \big[-8.61 + 3.54{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\big] \hspace{1.6em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\[8pt]
  &\approx e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}5t} \big[9.30e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}2.75}\big] \hspace{1.6em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\[8pt]
  &\approx 9.30e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(5t+2.75)} \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the identity
$\sin \theta = \cos(\theta-\textstyle\frac{\pi}{2})$ with
$\theta = 5t+2.75$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.4em} I(t) &\approx \mathrm{Im}\big[9.30e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(5t+2.75)}\big] \hspace{2em} [\text{by $(1)$ and $(2)$}] \\[8pt]
  &\approx 9.30\sin\hspace{0.05em}(5t+2.75) \\[8pt]
  &\answer{\approx 9.30\cos\hspace{0.05em}(5t+1.18)} \hspace{2em} [\text{since $2.75 - \textstyle \frac{\pi}{2} \approx 1.18$}]\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = I(t)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b19fb021-405d-4f87-861f-57db50190a0c/images/826559f4-1052-4b95-9c53-4601db6b6fc2/edddcb5f4484a3ee01b2a7e1928a31daa1879cc9.svg)


  Hence the highest current is
$\answer{9.30\hspace{0.25em}\text{mA}}$
and the
$1$st time it $\text{occurs}$ is at  $\answer{1.02\hspace{0.25em}\text{ms}}$
